body: I really like this idea.  Users via GitHub are going to start working from master or at least start reading the master docs.  I realized in #257 that it's hard to easily redirect them to latest stable release.
I suppose after beta-1 we can create a 1.0 branch and do all 1.0.X-SNAPSHOT work there and stop updating master.   We could start making pull reqs to 1.0 branch instead of master.
Yeah I held off on doing this because either it was going to cause a really nasty backwards merge, or someone as going to have to force push master- which I really wouldnt want to see, ever.
+1 for holding off until beta to do this.

I just noticed something today that I did inadvertently when trying out our new pull request model for forward merging of branches. I made a change in 1.0.0-alpha-1 and then forward merged into master and submitted pull requests for both at the same time.

The problem is that now 1.0.0-alpha-1 has a merge commit from the pull request that made it diverge from master by 1 commit. I'll like to do a merge forward to master with this merge commit and submit a pull request to fix this. 

In the future, a better model would be to do the changes in the earlier branch, submit pull request, merge forward, submit pull request. This will get increasingly complicated as we increase the number of concurrent versions that we'll need to issue bugfix commits to
Could add a 4th map reduce job that computes an initial set of rfiles for bulk loading.

Site was created and is now live.  Added any remaining issues from this ticket to the project website repo.

Rather than developing a custom monitoring tool for Fluo, it would be nicer to collect metrics in Fluo using the [dropwizard metrics library](https://dropwizard.github.io/metrics/3.1.0/).  This library allows metrics to be reported to Graphite, Ganglia, or JMX.  Reporting would only occur if configured by user in `fluo.properties`.  Instructions could be provided to help users set up and configure these monitoring tools for Fluo.

Looks good.  I ran the Split command on my own instance (for 10 tablets, 1 bit node size, and 10M max).  At first, I thought that the splitting below was incorrect as it was occurring at only lower order bits.  However, below is correct due to the 10M max:

```
> getsplits
62:01:00000000004c4b41
63:01:00000000001e8481
63:01:00000000003d0902

64:01:00000000000f4241
64:01:00000000001e8482
64:01:00000000002dc6c3
64:01:00000000003d0904
64:01:00000000004c4b45
64:01:00000000005b8d86
64:01:00000000006acfc7
64:01:00000000007a1208
64:01:0000000000895449
```
Built tarball in branch & verified that docs directory was present
After talking to @keith-turner, I am going to close this request for now.  More work needs to be combine the 2 twill applications into one and create a single Fluo admin script.

My thinking was that it would be nice if the fluo script names worked well in the global path namespace.  I was thinking git is a nice model for this.  I like how all git command are accessed w/ `git <command>`.  This model would work well for fluo, since fluo is short.  One main script to run all fluo commands `fluo <command>`.

I think we should be able to run on Mesos too.  YARN was chosen because users need Hadoop installed to run Accumulo.  However, we could have users that prefer Mesos and only allocate limited resources to Hadoop.  When #289 is done, we coud add a `fluo mesos (start|stop|status)` command for mesos.  

It might be a good idea to do this for the beta release so we don't get too bound to YARN.

In #292, a question came up on whether yarn properties should be configured with the oracle (i.e `io.fluo.oracle.num.instances` or with YARN prefix `io.fluo.yarn.oracle.instances`.  I think the deciding factory is whether or not YARN & Mesos should share properties.  This should be decided during the integration of Mesos in this ticket.  If they shouldn't be shared, the properties should be re-organized into `io.fluo.yarn.*` properties and `io.fluo.mesos.*`.
Need an IT that verifies things work properly when Accumulo and Fluo use different ZKs.

Would be nice to have an IT that runs two Fluo instances concurrently w/ different chroot config using the same zookeepers.  However I am thinking this could be a separate issue.  We kinda needed this test before this change.  I'll open an issue.
I tried to write an IT where Fluo and Accumulo use different ZKs by running another mini accumulo instance.  The test worked but slowed my machine to a crawl so I did not include it in f6df8296b
can this be closed?   given merge of #299
removed newAccumuloCurator() in  34b18a335f8

I tried to run the branch in YARN but it failed with the following error.  Do I have something misconfigured?


I was able to run a Fluo instance from the branch using local processes.  I think the exception above is only limited to YARN.
not sure whats going on w/ YARN.  I have been doing all of my testing using `fluo local`.  I will look into it.

> However, if the entire lib/ directory is loaded, exceptions are thrown because duplicate jars are being loaded. 

I don't understand why this exception occurs when loading all of lib, can you expand on this?

Twill automatically finds some jars and adds them to a bundled jar.  When I go to add more, some are duplicates and an exception is thrown (when it should just ignore duplicates).  See this [email thread](http://s.apache.org/lXj) and [TWILL-108](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TWILL-108) for more info.
+1.  I ran the stress test on my machine to verify.  It definitely seems faster.  Especially toward end of test.
This should also be done for `fluo mini stop`

Would be nice if this would page similar to the Accumulo shell's scan command

Should we rework phrasecount and quickstart examples to use this new feature?  Thats one way of testing this.  If we did that, maybe we could put the work in branch in phrasecount and quickstart repos for now.  Leaving master on phrasecount and quickstart based against alpha until beta is released.

Should have an IT that exercises `io.fluo.mini.start.accumulo`.  I was thinking that TestMiniBase could be modified for this, but took a look at it and decided against this.  Many test could extend TestMiniBase and it probably best if they all use the shared mini accumulo.  Would be better to have a single IT that starts its own minifluo which starts an accumulo.

> Would be nice if this would page similar to the Accumulo shell's scan command

What about `fluo scan -r row1 | less` ?

For the mini case, assuming mini writes out a props file somewhere that could be used to connect.. then scan could have an option for a props file.  Could do `fluo scan --props ../mini/mini.properties`

> What about `fluo scan -r row1 | less` ?

Was thinking about how this differs from accumulo shell.  If user stops paging, then accumulo shell stops doing work.  Would be nice to handle this when piping like [ACCUMULO-1706](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ACCUMULO-1706)
Yeah the stopping part was exactly what I was thinking- let the user page through it and stop when they want to.
I created a test that exercises MiniFluo (when it starts its own accumulo) in 1290086ca
+1 (would be really nice to make MiniIT use target, but other than that it looks good)
When you use 'fixes' or 'closes' followed by multiple issues in a commit message, GitHub will only close the first issue.  This issue was listed second.  Should it be closed?
My pull request for TWILL-108 was merged.  Once Twill releases 0.5.0-incubating, YarnAdmin can be changed in Fluo to load all libraries and this ticket can be closed.
I removed hadoop-minicluster from cluster pom.xml
I think this was done in #298.  In addition to making it possible to run mini from the command line, work on #298 also made it easy to run mini from code.
I ran the ITs on OS X recently.  Both runs took about 10min.  While nothing was done to fix this issue, I am going to close for now.  It can be re-opened if it becomes an issue again.

I think a good solution to this problem would be to make the level in the tree to which updates are pushed up configurable.   Stopping before level 0 would create multiple trees in the table, instead of a single tree.   To obtain the # of unique ints, would just need to scan all of the trees root nodes (once all notifications a processed).  The nice thing about making this configurable is that you can still get the crazy number of collisions if you want that for testing purposes.

In order to scan the root nodes at a particular level, the structure of the row would need to be changed.  I think changing it from 

```
<hash>:<level>:<nodes size>:<number> 
```

to

```
<level>:<hash>:<nodes size>:<number> 
```

Would allow one to easily scan level `05` and still avoid the problem for which the hash was added in #312. 

Also the Print command needs to be changed anyway.  It currently attempts to scan the entire tree, however after #343 this is not always feasible.
Saw this NPE again while running `fluo scan`

It looks like the TrieBasicIT & TrieMapRedIT are now taking a long time (~5 min & 1.5 min) with this commit.  While I think these changes should be the default (as they make Fluo run better at scale), could we make some them configurable and make the workers more aggressive when running MiniFluo or integration tests?  It would be nice to keep integration tests fast.

> It looks like the TrieBasicIT & TrieMapRedIT are now taking a long time (~5 min & 1.5 min) 

yikes!  I will look into fixing, that's no good.

What are your thoughts on adding test for this command?  I was debating w/ myself about this and did not come to a conclusion.  A reason for not having test is the code is fairly simple and calls out to code that does have tests. A reason to have test is that this command will be used alot and it would be annoying if if it did regress in some way and that was not caught before release.
See pull request #346
I think a test is a good idea.  I created #351.  Let me know if you agree with approach in the issue or have other ideas.

I like your approach for testing

+1
I just searched the for `user` in Files Changed and I think I got everything
I think I addressed all comments from review.. Let me know if I can rebase into one commit.

After making the changes in #360 I saw improvements.   I think I saw a peak rate of ~100K transactions per minute, but it was a week ago and my memory is a bit fuzzy.  Also it completed processing all notifications much more quickly because there were not many collisions.  I ran these test on m1.large instances.  They are cheap, but not that fast.  I wish I had kept some of the graphite plots.

After surpassing the collision problem I ran into another issue.   Tablets for levels within the tree were not balanced evenly across the cluster.  In one test run I had multiple tablets containing the root nodes, however many of these tablets ended up on one tserver.  I saw performance drop when lots of threads started trying to update the root nodes.   I killed the tserver w/ all the root nodes (forcing them to spread out across the tservers) and saw performance increase in subsequent test.
Resolved by PR #353
Interesting, it seems that nothing was throwing exceptions in the code?   I didn't see any added try/catch blocks in the patch.
Yes.  Nothing was throwing exceptions :-)
@keith-turner - I made Bytes immutable and created a MutableBytes object for core.  I want to do some more clean up if the basic concept is good.  Let me know what you think..

May be good to declare method and members final (the ones that at it makes sense for).

https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/essential/concurrency/imstrat.html

I timed the creation of 1 million Bytes & MutableBytes objects using different data and sizes: 

```
Time(ms) to create 1M byte[20] using Bytes=48 MutableBytes=4
Time(ms) to create 1M byte[2000] using Bytes=260 MutableBytes=5
Time(ms) to create 1M String[20] using Bytes=86 MutableBytes=63
```
I realized that Bytes could have a toByteBuffer() method that returns a read only ByteBuffer and does not copy the data.  I can create a follow on issue.
I moved the performance test to https://gist.github.com/mikewalch/800e4830cb3e2d12397e

The tests are failing for this branch due to a new test in the API module in master that just needs to be moved to core.  I will fix it after this pull requested is reviewed as I would like rebase after I squash the 11 commits on this branch into one.

I ran the performance test again and found a bug in the initial test.  Below are results with the test fixed and comparing the 2 implementations:

```
Instantiating each MutableBytes
Time(ms) to create 10M byte[20] using Bytes=97 MutableBytes=20
Time(ms) to create 10M byte[2000] using Bytes=2381 MutableBytes=19
Time(ms) to create 10M String[20] using Bytes=546 MutableBytes=488

Using MutableBytesFactory
Time(ms) to create 10M byte[20] using Bytes=81 MutableBytes=19
Time(ms) to create 10M byte[2000] using Bytes=2384 MutableBytes=19
Time(ms) to create 10M String[20] using Bytes=517 MutableBytes=473
```
Opened [ACCUMULO-3439](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ACCUMULO-3439) and submitted a patch.

+1

wow, that was a really small change
Work completed in fluo-io/fluo-dev#2

After looking on the [internet](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3368830/how-to-name-factory-like-methods) and talking offline to Keith, it makes sense to change Bytes.wrap() to Bytes.of() as this method could be considered a type conversion.  MutableBytes.wrap() should remain as this doesn't do a copy and just wraps the data given to the method.
Upgraded to hadoop 2.6.0 and this is no longer happening.
Not sure what I was thinking here.  `fluo.properties` does document the config at the moment.
I think this is no longer relevant w/ #317

A specific case we need to help users debug is collisions.  Work on #20 helps users see collisions are occurring at a macro level, however it offers no insight into specific row cols where collisions are happening. Maybe collision logging that could be turned on would be useful.
done in #346
